<div class="ten columns omega">
<h3>About RMS Titanic</h3>
<ul class="tabs">
<li class="tab active">
<h3 class="title">Introduction</h3>
<ul class="accordion-boxes slim">
<li class="unit ui-toggle active">
<h3 class="title">RMS Titanic</h3>
<div class="content">
<p><em>RMS Titanic</em> was a British registered four funnelled ocean liner built in 1912 for the transatlantic passenger and mail service between Southampton and New York.</p>
<p>Constructed at the Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast, Ireland Titanic was, on her maiden voyage, the largest vessel afloat.</p>
<p>On 10 April 1912 the <em>RMS Titanic</em> sailed from Southampton, England with 2,200 passengers and crew, four days later the <em>Titanic</em> collided with an iceberg and sank: 1500 people died and 700 survived. This website attempts to tell their story and that of the great ship with which their fate would be inextricably linked.</p><p>Was your relative on RMS Titanic?</p>
</div>
</li>
<li class="unit ui-toggle">
<h3 class="title">Passenger and Crew Search</h3>
<div class="content">Quickly find biographies by searching by surname or use other keywords to find relevant articles.
<form action="http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/titanic-search.php" id="cse-search-box">
<div>
<input name="cx" type="hidden" value="partner-pub-8229361356428053:6873164966"/>
<input name="cof" type="hidden" value="FORID:10"/>
<input name="ie" type="hidden" value="UTF-8"/>
<input name="q" size="20" type="text"/>
<input name="sa" type="submit" value="Search"/>
</div>
</form>

</div>
</li>
<li class="unit ui-toggle">
<h3 class="title">Quick Facts</h3>
<div class="content">
<div class="ibox info">
<p><strong>324</strong> <a href="/titanic-first-class-passengers/" title="Titanic First Class Passengers">1st class passengers</a>, <strong>201</strong> survived.<br>
<strong>277</strong> <a href="/titanic-second-class-passengers/" title="Titanic Second Class Passengers">2nd class passengers</a>, <strong>118</strong> survived.<br>
<strong>708</strong> <a href="/titanic-third-class-passengers/" title="Titanic Third Class Passengers">3rd class passengers</a>, <strong>181</strong> survived.<br>
<strong>885</strong> <a href="/titanic_crew_list/" title="Titanic Crew List">crew members</a>, <strong>212</strong> survived.<br>
<strong>13</strong> <a href="/titanic-postal-clerks/" title="Titanic Postal Clerks">postmen</a>/<a href="/titanic-orchestra/" title="Titanic Orchestra">musicians</a>, none survived.<br>
Grand total: <strong>2,207</strong> on board, <strong>712</strong> survived.</br></br></br></br></br></p>
<p>Length: 882 feet 9 inches<br>
Beam: 92 feet<br>
Gross tonnage: 46,328 tons<br>
Propulsion: Three propellers<br>
Engines: Two triple-expansion reciprocating steam engines<br>
One low-pressure Parsons turbine<br>
25 double-ended and 4 single-ended Scotch-type boilers<br>
159 coal burning furnaces<br>
Top speed : 23 knots.</br></br></br></br></br></br></br></br></p>
<p>For more detailed statistics see Lester Mitcham's <a href="/titanic-statistics.html" title="Titanic Statistics">The Statisics of the Disaster</a></p>
</div></div>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="tab">
<h3 class="title">People</h3>
<p><a href="http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/titanic-passenger-list/" title="RMS Titanic Passenger List">Passenger List</a> | <a href="http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/titanic-crew-list/" title="RMS Titanic Crew List">Crew List</a> | <a href="http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/titanic-survivors-list/" title="RMS Titanic Survivors">Survivors</a> | <a href="http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/titanic-victims-list/" title="RMS Titanic Victims">Victims</a></p>
<p><em>RMS Titanic</em> carried 2207 people. People all ages, people of great wealth and of bitter poverty. Unsuspecting witnesses to an event they could never have envisaged</p><p>If you could walk the decks of <em>RMS Titanic</em> you would hear a dozen or more languages being spoken with every imaginable dialect. Not surprisingly <em>RMS Titanic</em> is often described as a microcosm of society.</p><p>The route to understanding the <em>RMS Titanic</em> story is to learn about and understand the people that built her, the people that sailed on her, those that died and those that survived when she met her end.</p>Encyclopedia Titanica contains a biography for every single person that travelled on <em>RMS Titanic</em> on her maiden voyage as well as information about the places people came from and the ships her crew served on.<p><p>Constantly revised and updated by a dedicated crew of our own, Encyclopedia Titanica is the ultimate <em>RMS Titanic</em> resource.</p><p><a href="/titanic-search/" title="Titanic search">Use the search engine</a> to find people by name, perhaps even someone related to you or browse the comprehensive <em>RMS Titanic</em> Passenger List and Crew List.</p><p>You can also support the work of Encyclopedia Titancia in keeping alive the memory of the people by <a href="/contribute/guide/" title="RMS Titanic Research Guide">helping us tell the story</a> of people from your own area.</p>
</p></li>
<li class="tab">
<h3 class="title">History</h3>
<p>According to legend <em>RMS Titanic</em> was conceived at a dinner between <a href="/titanic-biography/lord-pirrie.html" title="Lord Pirrie">Lord Pirrie</a> of the Harland &amp; Wolff shipyard and <a href="/titanic-survivor/j-bruce-ismay.html" title="J. Bruce Ismay">Joseph Bruce Ismay</a>, Chairman of the White Star Line, at Downshire House, Lord Pirrie's London home.</p><p>With the introduction of the Lusitania and Mauretania Curnard had stolen a march on the White Star Line; with <em>Olympic</em>, <em>Titanic</em> and <em>Britannic</em> Bruce Ismay and Lord Pirrie saw an golden opportunity to regain the initiative and with it a hefty slice of the transatlantic passenger trade.</p>
<p>The new vessels would forsake speed for the increased safety and comfort that would come with a significant increase in scale. Fittings and appointments would also be improved over the competions. Lavish staterooms, a swimmings pool, squash raquet court, gymnasium, stylish cafe and plush a la carte restaurant would attract the wealthy, while significantly improved accommodation in other classes was also provded. Millionaires might grab the headlines but it would be steerage (Third Class) and the growing middle class (Second Class) that would drive economic success.</p>
<p>Having been laid down in 1909 it would take three years of construction and fitting out before <em>RMS Titanic</em> was ready for sea, commanded by veteran <a href="/titanic-victim/edward-john-smith.html" title="Captain Edward John Smioth">Captain Edward John Smith</a>. After brief sea trials she departed Southampton on 10 April 1912.</p><p>After brief stops and Cherbourg and Queenstown she turned her head to the Atlantic ocean never to return.</p>
</li>
<li class="tab">
<h3 class="title">Design</h3>
<p><em>RMS Titanic</em> was designed and constructed at the Harland &amp; Wolff shipyard in Belfast, Northern Ireland under the supervision of marine architect Alexander Carlisle and chief designer <a href="/titanic-victim/thomas-andrews.html" title="Titanic Designer Thomas Andrews">Thomas Andrews</a></p><p>She was 882 feet 9 inches in length and 92 feet in breadth. Her gross tonnage was 46,328 tons. Three propellers were driven by two four-cylinder, triple-expansion, inverted reciprocating steam engines and one low-pressure Parsons turbine. Steam was provided by 25 double-ended and 4 single-ended Scotch-type boilers fired by 159 coal burning furnaces that gave her a theoretical top speed of 23 knots.</p><p>Although she was the largest ship in the world, she was only fractionally greater in size than her sister ship <em>RMS Olympic</em>. <em>RMS Olympic</em> and <em>RMS Titanic</em> were constructed side-by-side and less than one year would elapse between their respective maiden voyages. They were practically identical in both appearance and fittings. A third sister <em>Britannic</em> would follow, but would enter World War One as a vast hospital ship; she would never see service as a passenger liner.</p><p>The fascination with RMS Titanic is not confined to the lives of her passengers and crew but in the fine technical details about which more is learnt all the time. On Encyclopedia Titanica you can view <em>RMS Titanic</em> <a href="/titanic-deckplans/" title="Titanic Deckplans">Deckplans</a> for a deck-by-deck view of the ship and read <a href="/articles/" title="Titanic articles">technical articles</a> and follow <a href="/titanic-discussions/">technical discussions</a> which explore this aspect of the <em>RMS Titanic</em> story in incredible detail.</p>
</li>
<li class="tab">
<h3 class="title">Culture</h3>
<p><em>RMS Titanic</em> forms part of our cultural landscape. Since 1912 she has been depicted in countless films and books.</p><p>Through art, drama and music her tragedy is replayed and reinterpreted and collections of her relics can be seen in museums and exhibitions across the glode.</p><p><em>RMS Titanic</em> has even entered the language: the phrase re-arranging deckchairs on the <em>Titanic</em> exemplifies a futile exercise and the essence of her tragedy has formed the metaphorical basis of many an academic thesis.</p>
<p>Encyclopedia Titanica enables you to learn about how the <em>RMS Titanic</em> has been reflected in contemporary culture; <em>Titanic</em> on film and record, in photographic image and in art.</p><p>You can also learn about the true stories that inspired the movie makers including <a href="/the-real-jack-dawson.html" title="The real Jack Dawson">The Real Jack Dawson</a>, the story of a real life <em>Titanic</em> victim who's namesake was the hero of James Cameron's 1997 epic <em>Titanic</em>.</p><p>You can also watch the rarest of all motion pictures: RMS Titanic archive film.</p><p><strong>Other Destinations</strong><br/><a href="/titanic-sheet-music/">Sheet Music</a> | <a href="/titanic-historic-recordings/">Recorded Music</a> | <a href="/titanic-animation/">Animation</a></p></li>
<li class="tab">
<h3 class="title">Community</h3>
<p>Titanic has spawned a thriving community. On our <a href="http://www.facebook.com/encyclopediatitanica" title="Encyclopedia Titanica Facebook Page">Facebook page</a> and <a href="/titanic-discussions/" title="Encyclopedia Titanica Message Board">discussion board</a> you'll meet historians, enthusiasts and the descendants of Titanic passengers and crew.</p><p>The members will be happy to answer your queries about <em>RMS Titanic</em> and help you with researching her history and the stories of the people who sailed on her.</p><p>If you would like to submit stories and pictures to encyclopedia Titanica you can join the <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/encyclopediatitanica/" title="Editorial Group">Editorial Group</a>.</p>
<p><a href="/register/" title="Register">Register</a> if you want to post on our forum.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<h3 class="title">New Pictures</h3>
<ul>
<li>
